title: South Africa vs Canada LIVE Rugby World Cup 2019: Latest score and updates
text:
Follow live updates from the Rugby World Cup as South Africa and Canada go head to head in Kobe.

The Springboks can all-but confirm their place in the quarter-finals of the competition with a bonus-point win over the Canadians.

The challenge posed by Kingsley Jones's men comes just four days after South Africa beat Italy 49-3. Unsurprisingly, head coach Rassie Erasmus has rung the changes for the clash, making 13 in total as he looks to keep his side fresh for the knockout stages. Follow our rolling coverage below:

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Key Points South Africa XV: Willemse, Gelant, De Allende, Steyn, Nkosi; Jantjies, Reinach; T Du Toit, Brits, Koch, Snyman, Mostert, Kolisi (capt), Smith, Louw

Canada XV: Coe; Hassler, Trainor, Hearn, Van der Merwe; Nelson, Mack; Buydens, Quattrin, Ilnicki, Olmstead, Baillie, Rumball, Heaton, Ardron (capt)

Springboks skipper Siya Kolisi admitted earlier this week that South Africa know very little about today’s opponents and, as such, need to concentrate on getting their own systems and execution right.

"It comes down to what we have been doing every week. We always look at the previous game and see where we can improve," he said. "You do look at the other team, their attacking players and how they kick.

"But we don’t really know what to expect from their individuals, so we will do our own preparations." It’s a big game today for Damian Willemse, who starts at full back less than a week after arriving in Japan as a late injury replacement.

Full-back Willemse replaces Jesse Kriel, who has been ruled out of the rest of the World Cup.

Erasmus says Willemse, who had a recent stint with Saracens, "would have probably made the World Cup squad if he wasn't injured".

Willemse, 21, added: "I'm really excited to play. I've been out for three months. I've got that hunger and it's been good to get some game time for Sarries."

Of the 13 changes made to the starting line-up, only Springboks captain Siya Kolisi and centre Damian de Allende have retained their places. South Africa head coach Rassie Erasmus has sent a firm warning to his players about today's clash, insisting there can't be any room for a let-up in intensity against a side that has so far shipped 111 points at the tournament.

The Springboks will seal their place in the quarter-finals with a bonus-point win, barring Italy pulling off a huge upset in their last game against New Zealand, and Erasmus has made 13 changes after Friday's 49-3 win against Italy.

"One of the areas which will be vital going into the knockout stages is intensity and big moments, and the intensity at which quarter-final and semi-final rugby is being played," Erasmus said this week.

"If this team doesn't at least match that or step up, they will struggle to stay in team selection and make the team. They know that, and that will be one of the challenges." Hello again! I'm in place at Kobe’s Misaki Stadium where the roof is once again on, making for typically humid conditions. As such, both teams will need to be vigilant when it comes to controlling possession and handling. All three previous games in Kobe — England vs United States, Scotland vs Samoa, Ireland vs Russia — have suffered from more than 30 handling errors each. But, in every case, the Tier One side has come through as the victor.

Advertisement Hello all and welcome to The Independent's live coverage of this morning's Rugby World Cup clash between South Africa and Canada.



I'll be bringing you all the live action, reaction and analysis from Kobe - so make sure to stay tuned!

What time does it start?

South Africa vs Canada kicks off at 7.15pm Japan Standard Time, which is 11.15am BST, on Tuesday 8 October.

Where can I watch it?

The match will be broadcast on ITV. Alternatively, you can live stream it via the ITV Hub on your smartphone, laptop or tablet.
